column4: I did something kind of stupid, I unchecked the box in the User and Groups window that made my user able to administer the system, and I now I'm not able to get into the user and groups window, is there any way I could get my user to have those privileges again?
i'm guessing you removed your user from the wheel group
then, as a user that *can" admin the system, add yourself back to that file, or brute force it using a rescue disk
I don't have any other users that can use root, I just installed ubuntu 2 days ago and I haven't created any users except for the one I created at the installation.
two options come to mind, being that it is such a new installation there
first, if you have nothing all that customized yet, re-install ... not the only choice, but less intimidating perhaps, so i mention it, not knowing your fluency/comfort
the other involves using the command line and booting from a rescue disk (like the ubuntu cd you installed from, probably)
vigr and add your username to the wheel group, after chrooting to your root partition

I've been using a few distros off and on for the past few months, but in a random fit of stupidity i accedentally took away the option to allow me to administer. I probably could handle the command line.
or "adduser generalcola wheel" after chrooting to the root partition
if either of those ring a bell, you can probably handle it just fine :)
or whatever the account really is called, like say, "adduser alex wheel"
the trick is, you need to do this as root, and you have effectively locked yourself out of "as root", hence why we brute-force it by :
step 1, boot from rescue cd, step 2, mount the root partition, step 3, manually edit that /etc/group file, using vigr or something or even the higher-level command adduser
thanks for the help, I'll go try that now
presuming your username is alex there, do grep alex /etc/group (or run "groups" as alex)
